text:
Riverside Drive, east side, from 86th to but not including 87th Streets.
About 1904.

Brown Brothers.

Riverside Park: The Soldiers and Sailors Monument located on Riverside Drive at West 89th Street. Memorial
Day Services are held there annually.
About 1905

Riverside Park at West 89th Street, showing the Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Monument, erected in 1902 to commemorate the valor of the Union soldiers in the Civil War. Paul Duboy was the sculptor.

About 1910

Gift Of Urbrock Collection

(1)
West 86th Street, east from Riverside Drive, showing the huge apartment houses that line this thoroughfare, surplanting the former 4 and 5 story private residences. Note St. Pauls M. E. Church in a line with the traffic officer.

May 1928.

George L. Balgue.

(2)
A view of No's. 351 and 349 which appear on the extreme left of No. 1 and still stand at this date.

August 15, 1938.

P. L. Sperr

Riverside Park: A set of 2 views in a generally northward direction from the Soldiers and Sailors Monument on the west side of the Drive at the head of West 89th Street. Buildings on the right, on the east side of the Drive, face this marginal park that skirts the North River; View 2 showing this aspect mainly.

June 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Park: A set of 2 views in a generally northward direction from the Soldiers and Sailors Monument on the west side of the Drive at the head of West 89th Street. Buildings on the right, on the east side of the Drive, face this marginal park that skirts the North River; View 2 showing this aspect mainly.

June 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Park, at West 89th Street, showing the Soldiers and Sailors Monument. It was erected in 1902 to commemorate the valor of those who died in defense of the Union during the Civil War. Paul E. Duboy is the sculptor. It is made of white marble in the form of a small circular Greek Temple with a peristyle of twelve Corinthian columns.

1936

W.P.A. Photo
Federal Writers Project

140 to 147 Riverside Drive, east side, north from W. 86th to 87th Streets, showing a block front of private residences (built in 1896 by Henry Cook, architect) that are about to be replaced by a modern 18 story apartment house at a cost of $2,500,000. An account to this effect is in the New York Times of August 7, 1938. Included in this plan are 4 additional dwellings, No. 351 W. 86th Street (right of No. 1) and No's. 348, 50 and 52 W. 87th Street (not seen). Dr. John A. Harriss, former department commissioner of police, occupied for years No. 140, the structure at the N.W. corner of W. 86th Street. No. 2 is a southward view from a point slightly to the north of W. 87th Street.

P.L. Sperr

August 15, 1938.
Views 1 and 2
